forbes-etal-2020-social.title: Social Chemistry 101: Learning to Reason about Social and Moral Norms
forbes-etal-2020-social.author:
Forbes, Maxwell  and
Hwang, Jena D.  and
Shwartz, Vered  and
Sap, Maarten  and
Choi, Yejin
forbes-etal-2020-social.paperMotivationText: Social norms are crucial in understanding the underlying causes and intents of people’s actions in narratives.
forbes-etal-2020-social.paperContributionText: The authors propose Social Chemistry, a formalism and an annotated dataset containing Rules-of-Thumb (RoT) and designed to study people's everyday social norms. They also propose a model to generate RoT.
forbes-etal-2020-social.paperResultsText: They find that their formalism and model generations are in line with MFT, based on correlations between moral foundations, political leaning and news reliability.
forbes-etal-2020-social.theoryOtherText: Hare et al. (1981), Kohlberg (1976), Theory of blame (Malle et al. 2014)
forbes-etal-2020-social.dataDomainOtherText: stories involving commonsense, stories about morally loaded situations
